content:
Creating a folder structure for your study group materials will help you keep your notes, resources, and meeting materials organized. Here's a suggested folder structure for your study group materials from November to January:

**Study Group (Nov-Jan)**

* **Meetings:**
	+ November 2022 (folder with meeting notes, agendas, and any shared resources)
	+ December 2022 (folder with meeting notes, agendas, and any shared resources)
	+ January 2023 (folder with meeting notes, agendas, and any shared resources)
* **Notes:**
	+ Comprehensive Exam Prep (folder with notes on specific topics, e.g., machine learning, algorithms, data structures)
	+ Study Guides (folder with study guides, flashcards, or concept maps)
	+ Review Materials (folder with review materials, e.g., practice quizzes, past exams)
* **Resources:**
	+ Shared Documents (folder with shared Google Docs, PDFs, or other files)
	+ Online Resources (folder with bookmarks or links to online resources, e.g., tutorials, videos, blogs)
	+ Textbooks and References (folder with electronic copies of textbooks, research papers, or other references)
* **Assignments and Projects:**
	+ Group Assignments (folder with group assignments, projects, or presentations)
	+ Individual Assignments (folder with individual assignments, e.g., practice problems, coding challenges)
* **Miscellaneous:**
	+ Meeting Schedules (folder with meeting schedules, reminders, and notifications)
	+ Communication (folder with emails, chat logs, or other communication with group members)

This folder structure should help you keep your study group materials organized, making it easier to review, study, and collaborate with your group members. You can customize the folders and subfolders to fit your specific needs and preferences.

Remember to keep your folder names and structures consistent across your different courses and study groups, so you can easily navigate and find the information you need.
